title: The Cap Seller and the Monkeys
author: Traditional

content.text: Once upon a time, in a small village nestled between rolling green hills, there lived a kind and hardworking cap seller named Raju.
Every morning, Raju would wake up with the sun, pack his colorful caps into a large, woven basket, and set off to sell them in the nearby towns and villages.
His caps were famous far and wide—some were bright red like ripe apples, others were deep blue like the evening sky, and a few were golden yellow, shimmering like sunlight.
People loved his caps, and Raju took great pride in his work.
One hot summer day, Raju had walked many miles under the blazing sun.
His basket was heavy, his feet were tired, and his throat was parched.
"Oh, how I wish for a cool breeze and a shady spot to rest," he sighed.
Just then, he spotted a tall, leafy tree at the edge of a dense forest. "Ah!
That looks like the perfect place to take a nap," he thought.
Without a second thought, he hurried toward the tree, placed his basket carefully beside him, and lay down in its cool shade.
The gentle rustling of the leaves and the soft chirping of birds soon lulled Raju into a deep sleep.
He slept so soundly that he did not notice the mischievous monkeys who lived in the trees above him.
The monkeys had been watching Raju for some time, their bright eyes sparkling with curiosity.
They had never seen such colorful caps before!
One by one, the monkeys climbed down from the branches, their tiny hands reaching out to touch the caps.
They chattered excitedly as they tried them on, admiring how the caps looked on their heads. "Ooh!
This one is red!" squeaked one monkey. "Mine is blue—it matches the sky!" giggled another.
Soon, every monkey was wearing a cap, and they scampered back up the tree, leaving Raju’s basket empty.
After a while, Raju woke up, stretching his arms and yawning.
He rubbed his eyes and sat up, ready to continue his journey.
But when he looked at his basket, his heart sank. "Oh no! Where are my caps?" he cried.
He searched under the tree, behind the bushes, and even called out, "Has anyone seen my caps?" But there was no answer.
Just then, Raju heard a faint rustling above him. He looked up and gasped.
There, perched on the branches, were the monkeys—each one wearing one of his beautiful caps!
Raju’s eyes widened in shock. "Those sneaky monkeys!" he muttered.
He tried to think of a way to get his caps back.
He waved his arms and shouted, "Give me back my caps at once!" But the monkeys only copied him, waving their arms and chattering loudly.
Raju thought hard. He remembered that monkeys love to imitate what they see.
So, he decided to try something clever.
He took off his own cap—the plain brown one he always wore—and threw it to the ground in frustration.
To his delight, the monkeys did the same!
One by one, they took off their caps and tossed them down from the tree.
Raju quickly gathered all the caps and placed them back into his basket, his heart filled with relief.
"Thank you, little monkeys," he said with a smile, though the monkeys only chattered in reply.
Raju picked up his basket and continued on his way, wiser and more careful than before.
From that day on, he always kept a close watch on his caps whenever he rested under a tree.
And so, with a happy heart, Raju returned home that evening, his basket full once more.
He told his family the tale of the clever monkeys, and they all laughed and clapped at his quick thinking.
As the stars twinkled in the night sky, Raju drifted off to sleep, dreaming of his next adventure—and this time, he made sure to keep his caps safe!
